00034 /** @file sym.h

00040 #ifndef ISPC_SYM_H
00041 #define ISPC_SYM_H

00047 class StructType;
00048 class ConstExpr;
00049 
00050 /**
00051    @brief Representation of a program symbol.
00052 
00053    The Symbol class represents a symbol in an ispc program.  Symbols can
00054    include variables, functions, and named types.  Note that all of the
00055    members are publically accessible; other code throughout the system
00056    accesses and modifies the members directly.
00057 
00058    @todo Should we break function symbols into a separate FunctionSymbol
00059    class and then not have these members that are not applicable for
00060    function symbols (and vice versa, for non-function symbols)?
00061  */
00062 
00063 class Symbol {
00064 public:
00065     /** The Symbol constructor takes the name of the symbol, its
00066         position in a source file, and its type (if known). */
00067     Symbol(const std::string &name, SourcePos pos, const Type *t = NULL,
00068            StorageClass sc = SC_NONE);
00069 
00070     /** This method should only be called for function symbols; for them,
00071         it returns a mangled version of the function name with the argument
00072         types encoded into the returned name.  This is used to generate
00073         unique symbols in object files for overloaded functions.
00074      */
00075     std::string MangledName() const;
00076 
00077     SourcePos pos;            /*!< Source file position where the symbol was defined */
00078     const std::string name;   /*!< Symbol's name */
00079     llvm::Value *storagePtr;  /*!< For symbols with storage associated with
00080                                    them (i.e. variables but not functions),
00081                                    this member stores a pointer to its
00082                                    location in memory.) */
00083     llvm::Function *function; /*!< For symbols that represent functions,
00084                                    this stores the LLVM Function value for
00085                                    the symbol once it has been created. */ 
00086     llvm::Function *exportedFunction;
00087                               /*!< For symbols that represent functions with
00088                                    'export' qualifiers, this points to the LLVM
00089                                    Function for the application-callable version
00090                                    of the function. */
00091     const Type *type;         /*!< The type of the symbol; if not set by the
00092                                    constructor, this is set after the
00093                                    declaration around the symbol has been parsed.  */
00094     ConstExpr *constValue;    /*!< For symbols with const-qualified types, this may store
00095                                    the symbol's compile-time constant value.  This value may
00096                                    validly be NULL for a const-qualified type, however; for
00097                                    example, the ConstExpr class can't currently represent
00098                                    struct types.  For cases like these, ConstExpr is NULL,
00099                                    though for all const symbols, the value pointed to by the
00100                                    storagePtr member will be its constant value.  (This
00101                                    messiness is due to needing an ispc ConstExpr for the early 
00102                                    constant folding optimizations). */
00103     StorageClass storageClass;/*!< Records the storage class (if any) provided with the
00104                                    symbol's declaration. */
00105     int varyingCFDepth;       /*!< This member records the number of levels of nested 'varying' 
00106                                    control flow within which the symbol was declared.  Having
00107                                    this value available makes it possible to avoid performing
00108                                    masked stores when modifying the symbol's value when the
00109                                    store is done at the same 'varying' control flow depth as 
00110                                    the one where the symbol was originally declared. */
00111     const Function *parentFunction; 
00112                               /*!< For symbols that are parameters to functions or are 
00113                                    variables declared inside functions, this gives the
00114                                    function they're in. */
00115 };
00116 
00117 
00118 /** @brief Symbol table that holds all known symbols during parsing and compilation.
00119 
00120     A single instance of a SymbolTable is stored in the Module class
00121     (Module::symbolTable); it is created in the Module::Module()
00122     constructor.  It is then accessed via the global variable Module *\ref m
00123     throughout the ispc implementation.
00124  */
00125 
00126 class SymbolTable {
00127 public:
00128     SymbolTable();
00129     ~SymbolTable();
00130 
00131     /** The parser calls this method when it enters a new scope in the
00132         program; this allows us to track variables that shadows others in
00133         outer scopes with same name as well as to efficiently discard all
00134         of the variables declared in a particular scope when we exit that
00135         scope. */
00136     void PushScope();
00137 
00138     /** For each scope started by a call to SymbolTable::PushScope(), there
00139         must be a matching call to SymbolTable::PopScope() at the end of
00140         that scope. */ 
00141     void PopScope();
00142 
00143     /** Adds the given variable symbol to the symbol table.
00144         @param symbol The symbol to be added
00145 
00146         @return true if successful; false if the provided symbol clashes
00147         with a symbol defined at the same scope.  (Symbols may shaodow
00148         symbols in outer scopes; a warning is issued in this case, but this
00149         method still returns true.) */
00150     bool AddVariable(Symbol *symbol);
00151 
00152     /** Looks for a variable with the given name in the symbol table.  This
00153         method searches outward from the innermost scope to the outermost,
00154         returning the first match found.
00155 
00156         @param  name The name of the variable to be searched for.
00157         @return A pointer to the Symbol, if a match is found.  NULL if no 
00158         Symbol with the given name is in the symbol table. */
00159     Symbol *LookupVariable(const char *name);
00160 
00161     /** Adds the given function symbol to the symbol table.
00162         @param symbol The function symbol to be added.
00163 
00164         @return true if the symbol has been added.  False if another
00165         function symbol with the same name and function signature is
00166         already present in the symbol table. */
00167     bool AddFunction(Symbol *symbol);
00168 
00169     /** Looks for the function or functions with the given name in the
00170         symbol name.  If a function has been overloaded and multiple
00171         definitions are present for a given function name, all of them will
00172         be returned and it's up the the caller to resolve which one (if
00173         any) to use.
00174 
00175         @return vector of Symbol pointers to functions with the given name. */
00176     std::vector<Symbol *> *LookupFunction(const char *name);
00177 
00178     /** Looks for a function with the given name and type
00179         in the symbol table.
00180 
00181         @return pointer to matching Symbol; NULL if none is found. */
00182     Symbol *LookupFunction(const char *name, const FunctionType *type);
00183 
00184     /** Returns all of the functions in the symbol table that match the given 
00185         predicate.
00186 
00187         @param pred A unary predicate that returns true or false, given a Symbol 
00188         pointer, based on whether the symbol should be included in the returned 
00189         set of matches.  It can either be a function, with signature 
00190         <tt>bool pred(const Symbol *s)</tt>, or a unary predicate object with 
00191         an <tt>bool operator()(const Symbol *)</tt> method.
00192 
00193         @param matches Pointer to a vector in which to return the matching
00194         symbols. 
00195      */
00196     template <typename Predicate> 
00197         void GetMatchingFunctions(Predicate pred, 
00198                                   std::vector<Symbol *> *matches) const;
00199 
00200     /** Returns all of the variable symbols in the symbol table that match
00201         the given predicate.  The predicate is defined as in the
00202         GetMatchingFunctions() method.
00203      */
00204     template <typename Predicate> 
00205         void GetMatchingVariables(Predicate pred, 
00206                                   std::vector<Symbol *> *matches) const;
00207 
00208     /** Adds the named type to the symbol table.  This is used for both
00209         struct definitions (where <tt>struct Foo</tt> causes type \c Foo to
00210         be added to the symbol table) as well as for <tt>typedef</tt>s.
00211 
00212         @param name Name of the type to be added
00213         @param type Type that \c name represents
00214         @param pos Position in source file where the type was named
00215         @return true if the named type was successfully added.  False if a type
00216         with the same name has already been defined.
00217         
00218     */
00219     bool AddType(const char *name, const Type *type, SourcePos pos);
00220 
00221     /** Looks for a type of the given name in the symbol table.
00222 
00223         @return Pointer to the Type, if found; otherwise NULL is returned.
00224     */
00225     const Type *LookupType(const char *name) const;
00226 
00227     /** This method returns zero or more strings with the names of symbols
00228         in the symbol table that nearly (but not exactly) match the given
00229         name.  This is useful for issuing informative error methods when
00230         misspelled identifiers are found a programs.
00231 
00232         @param name String to compare variable and function symbol names against.
00233         @return vector of zero or more strings that approximately match \c name.
00234     */
00235     std::vector<std::string> ClosestVariableOrFunctionMatch(const char *name) const;
00236     /** This method returns zero or more strings with the names of types
00237         in the symbol table that nearly (but not exactly) match the given
00238         name. */
00239     std::vector<std::string> ClosestTypeMatch(const char *name) const;
00240 
00241     std::vector<std::string> ClosestEnumTypeMatch(const char *name) const;
00242 
00243     /** Prints out the entire contents of the symbol table to standard error.
00244         (Debugging method). */
00245     void Print();
00246 
00247 private:
00248     std::vector<std::string> closestTypeMatch(const char *str, 
00249                                               bool structsVsEnums) const;
00250 
00251     /** This member variable holds one \c vector of Symbol pointers for
00252         each of the current active scopes as the program is being parsed.
00253         New vectors of symbols are added and removed from the end of the
00254         main vector, so searches for symbols start looking at the end of \c
00255         variables and work backwards.
00256      */
00257     std::vector<std::vector<Symbol *> *> variables;
00258     /** Because there is no scoping for function symbols, functions are
00259         represented with a single STL \c map from names to symbols.  A STL
00260         \c vector is used to store the function symbols for a given name
00261         since, due to function overloading, a name can have multiple
00262         function symbols associated with it. */
00263     std::map<std::string, std::vector<Symbol *> > functions;
00264     typedef std::map<std::string, const Type *> TypeMapType;
00265     /** Like variables, type definitions can be scoped.  A new \c TypeMapType
00266         is added to the back of the \c types \c vector each time a new scope
00267         is entered.  (And it's removed when the scope exits).
00268      */
00269     std::vector<TypeMapType *> types;
00270 };
00271 
00272 
00273 template <typename Predicate> void
00274 SymbolTable::GetMatchingFunctions(Predicate pred, 
00275                                   std::vector<Symbol *> *matches) const {
00276     // Iterate through all function symbols and apply the given predicate.
00277     // If it returns true, add the Symbol * to the provided vector.
00278     std::map<std::string, std::vector<Symbol *> >::const_iterator iter;
00279     for (iter = functions.begin(); iter != functions.end(); ++iter) {
00280         const std::vector<Symbol *> &syms = iter->second;
00281         for (unsigned int i = 0; i < syms.size(); ++i) {
00282             if (pred(syms[i]))
00283                 matches->push_back(syms[i]);
00284         }
00285     }
00286 }
00287 
00288 
00289 template <typename Predicate> void
00290 SymbolTable::GetMatchingVariables(Predicate pred, 
00291                                   std::vector<Symbol *> *matches) const {
00292     for (unsigned int i = 0; i < variables.size(); ++i)
00293         for (unsigned int j = 0; j < variables[i]->size(); ++j)
00294             if (pred((*variables[i])[j]))
00295                 matches->push_back((*variables[i])[j]);
00296 }

00298 #endif // ISPC_SYM_H
